qas.question: Of what was Magadha one of sixteen?
How does the Sanskrit translate Maha-Janapadas?
Where was the center of Magadha?
Where were there early records of the Magadha kingdom?
What time do the texts locating Magadha kingdom predate?

context: Magadha (Sanskrit: मगध) formed one of the sixteen <a0_0>Mahā-Janapadas<a0_0/> (Sanskrit: "<a1_0>Great Countries<a1_0/>") or kingdoms in ancient India. The core of the kingdom was the area of <a2_0>Bihar<a2_0/> south of the Ganges; its first capital was Rajagriha (modern Rajgir) then Pataliputra (modern Patna). Magadha expanded to include most of Bihar and Bengal with the conquest of Licchavi and Anga respectively, followed by much of eastern Uttar Pradesh and Orissa. The ancient kingdom of Magadha is heavily mentioned in Jain and Buddhist texts. It is also mentioned in the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Puranas. A state of Magadha, possibly a tribal kingdom, is recorded in <a3_0>Vedic texts<a3_0/> much earlier in time than <a4_0>600 BC.<a4_0/> Magadha Empire had great rulers like Bimbisara and Ajatshatru.
